title: 109_s4060
content: The "Effective Terrorists Prosecution Act of 2006" defines an unlawful enemy combatant as an individual who directly participates in hostilities against the United States. The determination of unlawful enemy combatant status by a Combatant Status Review Tribunal is not conclusive for the jurisdiction of military commissions. Section 948d of title 10, United States Code is amended by removing subsection (c) and redesignating subsection (d) as subsection (c). Section 948r is also amended to exclude statements obtained by coercion in military commissions. Additionally, military judges have discretion to exclude hearsay evidence deemed unreliable or lacking probative value. Section 949a(b)(2)(E)(ii) of title 10, United States Code is amended to allow the military judge to determine the reliability or probative value of evidence upon motion by counsel. Additionally, military judges have discretion to take certain actions if a substitute for classified exculpatory evidence is insufficient to protect the defendant's right to a fair trial. Section 949j(d)(1) of title 10, United States Code is amended to give the military judge the authority to dismiss charges entirely, dismiss specific charges, or take other actions in the interest of justice if a substitute for classified evidence is deemed insufficient. Additionally, military commission decisions will now be reviewed by the United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces instead of the Court of Military Commission Review. The United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces will review cases referred by the convening authority under section 950c of title 10, focusing on matters of law. The Court's scope of review is limited to legal issues. The United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces reviews cases referred by the convening authority under section 950c of title 10, focusing on legal matters. In subchapter VI of chapter 47A, the item relating to section 950f is amended. The United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces reviews cases referred by the convening authority under section 950c of title 10, focusing on legal matters. Chapter 47A of title 10, United States Code, is further amended to replace references to the Court of Military Commission Review with the United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces. The United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces replaces the Court of Military Commission Review in legal matters under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. SEC. 8. IMPLEMENTATION OF TREATY OBLIGATIONS. The Military Commissions Act of 2006 is amended to preserve the US's ability to prosecute enemy nationals for war crimes against US citizens and armed forces. The President's authority to interpret Geneva Convention obligations is removed. The Geneva Conventions' meaning and application are clarified, giving the President authority to promulgate rules subject to oversight. The Act is amended to ensure fair treatment of US citizens and armed forces in conflicts not of an international nature. The Act is amended to ensure fair treatment of US citizens and armed forces in conflicts not of an international nature, including modifications of war crimes offenses such as denial of trial rights. Clause (ii) of subparagraph (D) of paragraph (2) is amended to define "serious physical pain." SEC. 9. Restoration of Habeas Corpus for individuals detained by the United States is repealed. SEC. 10. Expedited judicial review of Military Commissions Act of 2006. The rules for civil actions challenging provisions of the Military Commissions Act of 2006 include filing in the US District Court for the District of Columbia and review by a three-judge panel. Judgments can be appealed directly to the Supreme Court. The rules for civil actions challenging provisions of the Military Commissions Act of 2006 include filing in the US District Court for the District of Columbia and review by a three-judge panel. Judgments can be appealed directly to the Supreme Court within specific time frames. The courts are required to expedite the disposition of such actions or appeals. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on October 17, 2006, applying to all pending cases without exception.
